questions.text: Which of the following drugs acts by inhibiting 1,3-beta-glucan synthase?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Caspofungin

Explanation:

Caspofungin, an echinocandin antifungal, inhibits 1,3-beta-glucan synthase, disrupting fungal cell wall synthesis and causing cell lysis and death.

  • Cell wall inhibiting antifungals: Act by inhibiting the enzyme 1,3-beta-glucan synthase, essential for fungal cell wall formation.
    • Caspofungin
    • Micafungin
    • Anidulafungin
  • Cell membrane inhibiting antifungals:

Drugs

Mechanism of action

Natamycin (Option A)

Binds to ergosterol in the fungal cell membrane, disrupting membrane integrity.

Terbinafine (Option D)

It inhibits squalene epoxidase, reduces ergosterol synthesis, and affects cell membrane integrity.

Amphotericin B

Binds to ergosterol, forming pores in the fungal cell membrane, leading to cell death.

Fluconazole, Itraconazole, Ketoconazole (Option B)

Inhibits ergosterol synthesis, affecting cell membrane function.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT true regarding Amphotericin B?

choices.text: Acts by binding to ergosterol in fungal cell membranes.
Liposomal AMB is associated with lower nephrotoxicity than conventional AMB.
AMB is absorbed orally, making it suitable for treatment with systemic mycoses.
Drug of choice for the treatment of cryptococcal meningitis.

questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) AMB is absorbed orally, making it suitable for treatment with systemic mycoses.

Explanation:

Amphotericin B (AMB) is not absorbed orally, it is administered intravenously (IV) to achieve therapeutic levels in the bloodstream and treat systemic fungal infections.

Aspect

Amphotericin B

Mechanism of Action

Binds to ergosterol in fungal cell membranes (Option A), forming pores that disrupt membrane integrity, leading to leakage of cellular contents and fungal cell death.

Preparation
  • Conventional Amphotericin B (c-AMB)
  • Amphotericin B lipid complex (ABLC)
  • Liposomal Amphotericin B (L-AMB)

Use

Cryptococcal meningitis (Option D), mucormycosis, coccidioidal meningitis.

Adverse Effects
  • Nephrotoxicity: Most notable with conventional Amphotericin B (c-AMB); less with liposomal formulations (Option B).
  • Fever, chills, and hypotension can be managed with pre-treatment (NSAIDs, antihistamines).
  • Anemia (requires erythropoietin treatment).
  • Renal tubular acidosis leads to electrolyte imbalances (hypomagnesemia, hypokalemia).
  • Arachnoiditis, when used intrathecally

questions.text: Which drug belongs to the triazole group of antifungals known for its broad spectrum against yeast and moulds, including mucormycosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Posaconazole

Explanation:

Posaconazole is the triazole antifungal known for its broad spectrum against yeast and moulds, including mucormycosis.

Imidazoles

Triazoles
  • Miconazole (Option A ruled out)
  • Clotrimazole (Option C ruled out)
  • Ketoconazole (Option D ruled out)
  • Posaconazole (Option B)
  • Fluconazole
  • Itraconazole
  • Voriconazole

 

Aspect

Posaconazole

Mechanism of Action

Inhibits fungal sterol 14α-demethylase, disrupting ergosterol synthesis in fungal cell membranes.

Spectrum of Activity

Broad spectrum against various fungi, including Aspergillus spp., Candida spp., and Mucorales (effective against mucormycosis).

Adverse Effects

Common: Nausea, abdominal pain, diarrhoea, headache, dizziness.

Rare: Anaemia, neutropenia, cardiac arrhythmias, visual disturbances.

Route of Administration

Absorption of oral suspension is enhanced by low pH and fatty foods.

questions.text: All of the following azoles are primarily excreted through bile except?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Fluconazole

Explanation:

  • Fluconazole is the only azole among the options that is primarily excreted via the kidneys (urine).
     
  • The rest of the azoles - Ketoconazole, Itraconazole, and Posaconazole - undergo hepatic metabolism and are primarily excreted via bile.
     
  • Therefore, Fluconazole stands out for its renal clearance and dose adjustments are required in renal impairment.
     

Excretion patterns of azoles:
 

Azole

Route of Excretion

Dose Adjustment in Renal Failure

Fluconazole

Renal (urine)

Yes

Ketoconazole

Hepatic (bile)

No

Itraconazole

Hepatic (bile)

No

Posaconazole

Hepatic (bile, feces)

No

 

Ketoconazole (Option A): Incorrect because it is extensively metabolized in the liver and eliminated via the biliary route.
 

Itraconazole (Option B): Incorrect because it is lipophilic, has hepatic metabolism, and is excreted mainly in bile.
 

Posaconazole (Option C): Incorrect as it is also primarily excreted via feces, indicating biliary excretion.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman visits the dermatology clinic with a persistent and intensely itchy rash on her arms, legs, and trunk. She mentions that over-the-counter antihistamines have provided minimal relief. Which azole drug with antipruritic effects would be most suitable for managing her condition?
questions.solution:
• Sertaconazolean azole antifungal, possesses anti-inflammatory and antipruritic properties, making it well-suited for managing dermatological conditions associated with itching.
  • Fluconazole, Itraconazole, Voriconazole, and Posaconazole are other azole drugs that lack significant anti-pruritic properties.

questions.text: A kidney transplant patient receiving cyclosporine develops a new fungal infection and is prescribed ketoconazole for treatment. What is the potential consequence of adding ketoconazole to the patient's regimen?

choices.text: Elevated risk of toxicity with cyclosporine
No significant interaction between ketoconazole and cyclosporine

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Elevated risk of toxicity with cyclosporine.

Explanation:

  • Ketoconazole is a strong CYP3A4 inhibitor.
     
  • Cyclosporine is metabolized by CYP3A4. When ketoconazole is co-administered, it inhibits cyclosporine metabolism, leading to elevated blood levels.
     
  • This significantly increases the risk of cyclosporine-induced toxicity, especially nephrotoxicity and neurotoxicity.
     

Drug Interactions:

 

 

Drug

Mechanism

Impact on Cyclosporine

Cyclosporine

Immunosuppressant; CYP3A4 substrate

Narrow therapeutic index; toxic if elevated

Ketoconazole

CYP3A4 inhibitor

Reduces metabolism → ↑ cyclosporine levels

 

Adverse Effects of Ketoconazole:

 

System

Adverse Effects

Hepatic

Hepatotoxicity (boxed warning); can be severe or fatal

Endocrine

Inhibits steroidogenesis → ↓ cortisol/testosterone → gynecomastia, impotence

GI

Nausea, vomiting, abdominal discomfort

Skin

Pruritus, rash

QT Prolongation

Risk of torsades de pointes when combined with other QT-prolonging drugs

 

Decreased effectiveness of cyclosporine (Option A):
Incorrect. Ketoconazole increases, not decreases, cyclosporine levels by inhibiting its metabolism.
 

No significant interaction between ketoconazole and cyclosporine (Option C):
Incorrect. The interaction is clinically significant; it mandates dose adjustment and close monitoring.
 

Enhanced elimination of cyclosporine (Option D):
Incorrect. Ketoconazole slows elimination by inhibiting CYP3A4, leading to drug accumulation.

questions.text: A 23-year-old man comes to the dermatology OPD. After examination, a diagnosis of onychomycosis was made, and he was started on oral terbinafine. What is the mechanism of action of this drug?

choices.text: Formation of pore in ergosterol membrane

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Inhibition of squalene epoxidase

Explanation:
 

Aspects

Terbinafine

Mechanism of action

Competitive inhibition of squalene epoxidase (Option C)

↓

Accumulation of squalene within fungal cells

↓

Inhibition of ergosterol synthesis

↓

Disruption of fungal cell membrane integrity

↓

Fungicidal action

Features

It has a high affinity for sebum and thus accumulates in sebum, stratum corneum and nails.

Uses

  • Topical: Used for treating tinea infections (ringworm) and pityriasis versicolor (fungal skin infection).
  • Oral: DOC for onychomycosis (fungal infection of the nails), tinea capitis (scalp ringworm), and extensive fungal lesions.

It is also used in oromucosal candidiasis as an alternative to fluconazole.

Side effects

Taste disturbance and rash; topical application causes dryness, itching and irritation.

Inhibition of thymidylate synthase (Option A)

  • Flucytosine (5-FC) converts into 5-fluorodeoxyuridylic acid within the fungal cell and acts as an inhibitor of thymidylate synthase.
  • It is a narrow-spectrum fungistatic agent active towards Cryptococcus neoformans and chromoblastomyces.

Inhibition of lanosterol 14-methylase (Option B)

  • Azoles inhibit fungal cytochrome P450 enzyme - lanosterol 15-methylase, which results in abnormal membrane formation.\
  • It is a broad-spectrum antifungal agent that is active against dermatophytes, candida and other deep fungal infections (except mucormycosis)

Formation of pore in ergosterol membrane (Option D)

  • Amphotericin B has lipophilic and lipophobic sides, forming micropores in the ergosterol membrane of the fungal wall.
  • It is a broad-spectrum fungicidal agent effective against Candida, Histoplasma, Sporothrix, Blastomycosis, and Leishmania.

questions.text: An 18-year-old high school student presents to the dermatology outpatient clinic with symptoms of tinea pedis and tinea capitis. The dermatologist opts for an antifungal agent that inhibits microtubules within fungal cells, thereby preventing mitosis. Which drug was most likely prescribed?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Griseofulvin

Explanation:

Aspects

Griseofulvin

MOA

Inhibition of microtubules within the fungal cells, thus inhibiting mitosis.

It results in the formation of multi-nucleated and stunted fungal hyphae.

Features

  • Keratinophilic thus gets deposited in high concentration in Stratum corneum, hair and nails
  • Plasma half-life is 24 hours

Uses

DOC in Superficial fungal infections such as Tinea.

(T. capitis- most effective; T.curis , T.unguium, T.corporis- less effective; T. versicolor – it is not effective)

Side effects

  • Headache
  • Neuritis
  • Hepatitis
  • Photosensitivity
  • Disulfiram like reaction

questions.text: A 65-year-old diabetic patient is admitted to the ICU with meningitis. He reported contact with pigeon droppings two weeks prior. India ink staining of his CSF sample confirmed Cryptococcus neoformans infection. What is the most appropriate drug combination for treating this fungal infection?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Amphotericin B + Flucytosine

Explanation:

The treatment of choice for cryptococcal meningitis combines IV Amphotericin B and IV Flucytosine.

 

Mechanism of action

Uses

Side effects

Amphotericin B

(Polyene antibiotic molecule)

Forms micropores in the ergosterol membrane.

Cryptococcus neoformans

Leishmania

Nephrotoxicity

Allergic reaction

Arachnoiditis

Anemia

Flucytosine

(pyrimidine antimetabolite)

Inhibitor of thymidylate synthase

Cryptococcus neoformans Chromoblastomyces.

Dose-dependent marrow suppression

Enteritis.

Caspofungin + Flucytosine (Option A) is used in the treatment of systemic candidiasis in an immunocompromised patient

Voriconazole + Caspofungin (Option C) is used to treat invasive aspergillosis.

Amphotericin B + Posaconazole (Option D)  is used in the treatment of mucormycosis
